title: British Prime Minister Forced to Delay Crucial Vote on Brexit Deal
text:
Text size

Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister, has been forced to postpone a key vote in Parliament that was aimed at getting his Brexit agreement approved for the U.K. to leave the European Union.

However Johnson said he was not dismayed by the result and was resolute he would not negotiate a delay to Brexit.

If a deal is not approved by Parliament Johnson is required by law to ask the European Union for a three-month delay to Brexit. Johnson has always said he would not delay Brexit but would also abide by the law—without explaining how he would achieve this.

He reiterated on Saturday: “I will not negotiate a delay with the EU and neither does the law compel me to do so.”

However, later in the day the British government formally asked the European Union to delay the country’s departure from the bloc, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Earlier in the day politicians had gathered Saturday morning for a historic meeting in the House of Commons—the first time they had assembled on a Saturday since Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands. It marked only the fourth Saturday they have met in 80 years.

Johnson’s plans have been frustrated by moves from opponents to try to delay the legislation again and send lawmakers home without voting on the deal in a move to derail Brexit.

Oliver Letwin, a former Conservative minister, tabled an amendment to delay agreeing on any deal until all the legislation needed to implement it has been passed through Parliament.

This was carried by 322 votes to 306, which means the politicians withheld approval of the prime minister’s deal until the legislation to enact it is passed.

The motivation was to remove any possibility of Britain crashing out of the EU without a deal.

In the U.S., geopolitical concerns, including Brexit and trade, weighed on stock indexes on Friday.

Earlier in the day Johnson had told Parliament: “I do hope in assembling for the purposes of a meaningful vote that we will indeed be allowed to have a meaningful vote. I hope...that this is the moment when we can finally achieve that resolution and reconcile the instincts that compete within us.” But it was not to be.

Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the opposition, who said he would refuse to back the prime minister’s withdrawal deal, had said he wants the people to have another say on Brexit.

He had told Parliament: “Voting for a deal today won’t end Brexit. It won’t deliver certainty and the people should have the final say. I totally understand the frustration and the fatigue across the country and in this House. But we simply cannot vote for a deal that is even worse than the one this House rejected three times.”

On a day of high drama, thousands of people marched through central London calling for another “People’s Vote” to check that the U.K. is happy to leave the EU under the new withdrawal agreement.

They converged on Westminster as MPs debated the deal in the Commons. The march, which began at midday, started on Park Lane and was to end in Parliament Square.
